chapter.title: Spacewalk
chapter.para: This chapter discusses how to setup a Spacewalk server to test the MSAT scripts. Without a Spacewalk server (or Satellite server for that matter), it is hard to understand what the MSAT scripts do. Experimenting with the scripts is, in our opinion, very important.

warning.title: Get a working Spacewalk server first
warning.para: Setting up a Spacewalk server is cumbersome. Hence, we advice the reader to strictly follow the instructions given. Once a working Spacewalk server is at your disposal, it is easier to tweak or customize.

chapter.para:
In this chapter, we ask the reader to download items. We give an estimation of the download time. It is based on our own tests. Since downloads can depend on the speed of your local ISP (Internet Service Provider), we did a test via www.speedtest.net. The results were:
Speedtest results
test speed
ping 6 ms
download 7.71 Mbps
upload 0.84 Mbps
Still, downloads depend on the providing server. So, a higher ISP speed is no guarantee for better download times.

Setting up a spacewalk server, consists of a number of steps. We mention them here and elaborate on them in later sections. We think that it is important to give the recipe here in order to get the concept accross:
Download the Fedora 20 DVD ISO image and store it on the Linux host on which we install the Spacewalk KVM machine.
Prepare a Linux host on which we can install a Fedora 20 x86_64 KVM machine. On the host, enough memory (>4 GB) and disk space (> 300 GB, initially 80 GB will do), must be made available to the Spacewalk node.
Install the Fedora 20 distribution on the KVM machine and configure the system.
Install Spacewalk 2.1 on the Fedora 20 KVM machine and configure Spacewalk.
Create a minimal working Spacewalk server by filling it with CentOS 5.8 RPM's and creating a kickstartable tree.
Create a GPG key pair to sign RPM's with.
Test the Spacewalk server by provisioning a simple CentOS 5.8 system. By provisioning we mean: automatic installation, registration and configuration.
In the remainder of the chapter we discuss the steps. We keep the amount of information limited. In appendix ... we show screen dumps and extra information.
